strategic_profile.executive_summary: St. Louis University is a private Jesuit research university known for its health sciences, business, and liberal arts programs, fostering a commitment to service and social justice.
strategic_profile.market_position: Mid-tier research university with strong regional presence.
strategic_profile.admissions_philosophy: Holistic review emphasizing academic rigor, extracurricular involvement, and alignment with Jesuit values of service and community.

analyst_takeaways.takeaway: Strong potential for growth in specialized research areas.
Brand reputation benefits from Jesuit affiliation and urban location.
Admission selectivity is moderate, allowing for diverse student body.
Opportunities to enhance alumni engagement for fundraising initiatives.

campus_dynamics.social_environment: Active campus life with numerous student organizations, strong community service focus, and blend of traditional and urban experiences.
campus_dynamics.transportation_impact: Located in an urban setting, good public transit access, but parking can be a challenge. Walkable campus core.
campus_dynamics.research_impact: Significant contributions in health sciences (especially medicine and public health), aerospace engineering, and environmental research. Growing interdisciplinary initiatives.

current_status.test_policy_details: Saint Louis University has a standardized-test-optional undergraduate admission process. This means applicants can choose whether or not to submit ACT/SAT scores as part of their application for admission. Test scores are not required for admission or scholarships, and students who do not submit scores will not be disadvantaged. If students choose to submit test scores, SLU does not accept superscores; applicants should send their composite score and all subscores from each completed test. International students are still required to demonstrate English proficiency, which may necessitate the submission of a test score.

longitudinal_trends.notes: Official, comprehensive admissions data (applications, admits, enrolled) for the Class of 2029 (entering Fall 2025) is not yet publicly released by Saint Louis University. General acceptance rates for '2025' or '2025-2026 admissions cycle' found in some sources often refer to prior academic years or are projections rather than final, specific figures for this graduating class year.
Data for the 2024-25 academic year, corresponding to the class entering Fall 2024.
Data for the 2023-24 academic year, corresponding to the class entering Fall 2023.
Data for the class entering Fall 2022. The enrolled figure specifically refers to the first-time, full-time freshman class.
Data from the 2021-2022 Common Data Set for the class entering Fall 2021.

gpa.notes: St. Louis University has a holistic admissions process. The weighted GPA average for admitted students is 3.95, and the unweighted average is 3.9. Most incoming freshmen graduate in the top quarter of their high school class.

testing.policy_note: Test-optional. Superscore not accepted. Self-reporting allowed.

demographics.notes: First-generation percentage is based on the 2025 profile of first-year students. Legacy status is considered by St. Louis University, but a specific percentage of legacy students is not available in the provided search results.

colleges.housing_profile: college_name: College of Arts and Sciences; housing_profile: First-year students typically reside in traditional residence halls such as Fusz Hall, Grand Hall, Griesedieck Complex (Clemens, Walsh, Griesedieck halls), Reinert Hall, and Spring Hall, which offer single, double, and suite-style rooms with varying bathroom configurations (communal, semi-private, private). Many of these halls provide common areas, study lounges, laundry facilities, and dining options. Upperclassmen can choose from apartment-style living in Grand Forest, Marchetti Towers, or Village Apartments, featuring private bedrooms, shared living/kitchen/laundry facilities. Students can also join Learning Communities focused on humanities or life sciences within designated residence halls.; student_archetype: Inquisitive and broadly-minded students interested in diverse fields from English to Biology and Physics, with a commitment to critical thinking and ethical engagement, aligned with SLU's Jesuit tradition of comprehensive education.; strategic_fit_advice: Ideal for students seeking a foundational liberal arts education, who are eager to explore various disciplines and develop strong analytical and communication skills before specializing, often with a bent towards social justice and community involvement.

colleges.housing_profile: college_name: Richard A. Chaifetz School of Business; housing_profile: First-year students typically live in traditional residence halls like Grand Hall (opened in 2017 with suite-style rooms, maker space, and business incubator) or other freshman dorms. Upperclassmen can opt for apartment-style living on campus. Students may also consider the 'Ethical Leaders in Business' learning community.; student_archetype: Ethical, courageous, and career-aspirant students who value a rigorous curriculum, hands-on experiences, and a strong alumni network, committed to applying business theory to real-world settings and leading for the greater good.; strategic_fit_advice: Suited for aspiring business leaders and entrepreneurs who thrive in a collaborative environment, are committed to ethical practice, and wish to leverage a broad Jesuit university network for career development.

colleges.name: Trudy Busch Valentine School of Nursing

majors.name: Nursing
majors.special_requirements: Application deadline of December 1st for Regular Decision. Direct entry only for freshman admission. High school GPA of 3.79 recommended. Admission is competitive.

core_courses: NURS 1000 Introduction to Professional Nursing (3 cr)
NURS 2110 Fundamentals of Nursing Clinical (2 cr)
NURS 3010 Medical-Surgical Nursing I Clinical (2 cr)
NURS 4010 Community Health Nursing Clinical (2 cr)
NURS 4900 Transition to Professional Practice (3 cr)
BIOL 1510 General Biology I Laboratory (1 cr)
CHEM 1115 General Chemistry I Laboratory (1 cr)

notable_professors: Teri Murray (Trudy Busch Valentine School of Nursing)
majors.notes: Highly competitive program. Regular Decision application deadline is December 1st. Students must maintain a 3.00 GPA in required science and nursing courses. Data source: Saint Louis University Academic Catalog 2025-2026.

colleges.housing_profile: college_name: Trudy Busch Valentine School of Nursing; housing_profile: First-year students often choose the Health Sciences Learning Community in Reinert Hall, which offers rooms with private bathrooms and is conveniently located near health professions courses. Other first-year students reside in various traditional halls. Upperclassmen utilize on-campus apartments. Graduate students have options like Ignacio Hall and Robert May Hall.; student_archetype: Compassionate, highly skilled, and dedicated individuals committed to providing effective patient care, valuing state-of-the-art facilities, advanced instruction, and innovative approaches in nursing.; strategic_fit_advice: Ideal for students passionate about a career in nursing, from traditional BSN to advanced practice and doctoral programs, who desire a scientific and values-based education with extensive clinical experience and a focus on pioneering healthcare practices.

colleges.name: School of Social Work
colleges.housing_profile: college_name: School of Social Work; housing_profile: Students generally reside in standard university housing, with freshmen in traditional dorms and upperclassmen in campus apartments. Graduate students can opt for Ignacio Hall or Robert May Hall.; student_archetype: Empathetic, socially conscious, and actively engaged individuals committed to advocating for vulnerable populations and working towards a more just society, reflecting SLU's mission of service.; strategic_fit_advice: Recommended for students with a strong commitment to social justice, community service, and direct practice in social work, who are eager to develop skills to address societal challenges and support individuals and families.

colleges.housing_profile: college_name: Doisy College of Health Sciences; housing_profile: First-year students are strongly encouraged to join the Health Sciences Learning Community in Reinert Hall, a popular choice due to its proximity to health professions courses and private bathrooms. Other first-year students reside in various traditional halls. Upperclassmen can choose from on-campus apartments. Graduate students have dedicated housing in Ignacio Hall and Robert May Hall.; student_archetype: Ambitious and compassionate students passionate about various health professions (e.g., physical therapy, nursing, occupational therapy, nutrition), eager for interdisciplinary collaboration and hands-on clinical experience.; strategic_fit_advice: An excellent fit for students committed to a career in healthcare who seek a supportive learning environment, opportunities for shadowing experiences at SLU Hospital, and a curriculum integrating academic knowledge with practical skills.

majors.name: Social Work
majors.special_requirements: Admission to the professional sequence of the program, typically after sophomore year, requires a separate application.

core_courses: SWRK 1000 Introduction to Social Work (3 cr)
SWRK 2000 Social Welfare Policy and Services (3 cr)
SWRK 2200 Human Behavior and the Social Environment I (3 cr)
SWRK 2210 Human Behavior and the Social Environment II (3 cr)
SWRK 3000 Social Work Practice I (3 cr)
SWRK 3010 Social Work Practice II (3 cr)
SWRK 3020 Social Work Research Methods (3 cr)
SWRK 4900 Senior Seminar in Social Work (3 cr)
electives: Social Work electives (6 credits from 3000-level or above)

notable_professors: Michael Mancini (School of Social Work)
majors.notes: Minimum 2.50 cumulative GPA and SWRK 1000 with a C or better required for admission to the professional sequence. Data source: Saint Louis University Academic Catalog 2025-2026.

colleges.housing_profile: college_name: College for Public Health and Social Justice; housing_profile: First-year students may participate in the Health Sciences Learning Community located in Reinert Hall, which offers rooms with private bathrooms and amenities like study rooms and a chapel. Other first-year students reside in general residence halls (Fusz, Grand, Griesedieck, Spring). Upperclassmen have apartment options (Grand Forest, Marchetti Towers, Village Apartments), and graduate students can choose Ignacio Hall or Robert May Hall, with Ignacio Hall offering private rooms and bathrooms. The College itself moved to the Marvin and Harlene Wool Center in January 2025, suggesting modern academic facilities.; student_archetype: Community-minded and action-oriented students dedicated to addressing complex health problems and promoting social well-being through innovative and collaborative solutions, valuing hands-on experience and community partnerships.; strategic_fit_advice: Recommended for students with a strong interest in health administration, public health, or health analytics, who are driven by a desire to serve communities, work for social justice, and engage in impactful research and practical applications.

colleges.name: School of Education
colleges.housing_profile: college_name: School of Education; housing_profile: Students generally reside in standard university housing, with freshmen in traditional dorms (Fusz, Grand, Griesedieck, Reinert, Spring) and upperclassmen in campus apartments (Grand Forest, Marchetti Towers, Village Apartments). Graduate students have options like Ignacio Hall or Robert May Hall.; student_archetype: Dedicated and service-oriented individuals passionate about learning, teaching, and improving educational outcomes, particularly with a focus on urban education and community impact.; strategic_fit_advice: Ideal for students aspiring to careers in teaching, educational leadership, or related fields who are committed to fostering learning environments and making a difference in the lives of students and communities.

colleges.housing_profile: college_name: School of Science and Engineering; housing_profile: First-year students can join the 'Engineering and Innovation' Learning Community, likely housed in a residence hall like Grand Hall which features a maker space with 3D printers and a business incubator. Other freshmen reside in general dorms. Upperclassmen can opt for campus apartments.; student_archetype: Ambitious problem-solvers, innovators, and critical thinkers drawn to STEM fields, eager for hands-on learning, convergent research experiences, and opportunities to collaborate with professors to solve complex global problems.; strategic_fit_advice: Strongly recommended for students with a solid STEM background who are interested in aerospace engineering, aviation, technology, and other sciences, and who seek a curriculum that emphasizes research, practical application, and career success.

colleges.name: School for Professional Studies
colleges.housing_profile: college_name: School for Professional Studies; housing_profile: Students typically utilize general university housing options, which include traditional residence halls for younger undergraduates and apartment-style living for upperclassmen. Graduate housing options like Ignacio Hall and Robert May Hall are available for eligible students.; student_archetype: Driven and practical learners, often non-traditional students or those balancing other commitments, seeking flexible and accessible programs to advance their professional skills and career.; strategic_fit_advice: Ideal for working professionals or adult learners looking for flexible online or evening programs, who are focused on career advancement and require practical, relevant education.

application_deadlines.notes: This plan is for students who are committed to attending SLU if admitted. An Early Decision Agreement must be signed. Admission status notification begins December 1.
This plan is non-binding. The application deadline for Nursing, Flight Science, Occupational Therapy, and Physical Therapy majors is also December 1.
This plan is binding. If admitted, applicants are committed to attending and required to withdraw all applications from other institutions. Admission status notification begins February 1.

This is the preferred deadline; applications will continue to be accepted and scholarships awarded while space is available. Admission decisions released by April 15 for those with completed applications by March 16, or within 30 days after submission of all documents.

supplemental_requirements.details: All applicants for freshman admission must submit a personal essay when they apply through the Common Application or the SLU online application. No specific supplemental essay prompts beyond this personal statement were found for general undergraduate admission.

An audition is required for admission to the music program. Prospective music majors must pass an entrance audition to declare the music major. For pianists, two memorized works from contrasting style periods (e.g., Baroque, Classical, Romantic, Impressionist, 20th Century) at an late-intermediate level or higher are required. Vocalists must prepare two contrasting selections from standard musical theater repertoire (golden age to contemporary), standard classical repertoire (art song or aria in English, traditional folk song or spiritual), or standard classical repertoire (art song or aria in a language other than English). Auditions can be arranged on-campus or submitted via a file-sharing service like Dropbox or Google Drive, or through the Get Acceptd app. Auditions completed/submitted by March 1 are considered for music scholarships.

No undergraduate architecture portfolio requirement was found for St. Louis University (main campus in St. Louis, MO). The university offers a Bachelor of Science in Architecture. While some search results mention portfolio requirements for "studio art" or for architecture programs, these refer to different institutions (e.g., Washington University in St. Louis) or a different campus (Saint Louis University, Baguio City, Philippines).

holistic_factors.specific_differentiators: Saint Louis University employs a holistic review process rooted in its Jesuit values, looking at the 'whole package' of an applicant beyond just academic metrics. They offer a test-optional admissions process and emphasize factors such as leadership qualities, service to the community, and personal character in addition to academic performance.

major_selection_tactics: Consider starting undeclared, especially within the College of Arts and Sciences (CAS). SLU acknowledges that deciding on a major takes time and offers extensive support for "Still Deciding" students. The College of Arts and Sciences, with over 60 majors, minors, certificates, and micro-credentials, explicitly allows students to explore various academic pathways before declaring an official major. All CAS students, including those who are undeclared, are assigned an academic advisor to guide them through the major exploration process.

Leverage university resources for major exploration. St. Louis University provides numerous resources to help students identify a major that aligns with their interests, strengths, and career goals. These include professional academic advisors who assist with course selection and major exploration, career counselors, and assessment tools like Focus 2 and "What Can I Do With This Major?". Students are also encouraged to connect with faculty members, attend events like the Major Exploration Station during SLU 101, and explore campus organizations and internships to discover their passions.

Understand that changing majors is common and often straightforward for many programs. About a third of students change majors at least once. For many general programs, the process of switching majors is relatively easy and may only require paperwork. However, be aware that some specific programs, such as Physical Therapy, may have distinct application requirements that need to be met as a freshman.

Research program-specific requirements and timelines, particularly for competitive or specialized fields. While the overall acceptance rate for St. Louis University is moderately selective (around 81-85%), some programs, like Physical Therapy, have specific application requirements that must be fulfilled when applying as a freshman. Although explicit major-specific acceptance rates are not readily available, understanding these unique requirements is crucial for strategic major selection in specialized areas.
application_strategy.alternate_major_strategy: alternate_major_strategy: If applying to competitive major, list backup in different college. Example: if applying to CS in Engineering, list Cognitive Science as alternate.; internal_transfer_difficulty: Competitive internal transfer process for impacted majors

financials.notes: Full undergraduate tuition may be covered for first-time freshmen with a combined parent AGI of $60,000 or less.

scholarships.name: Presidential Scholarship
scholarships.amount: Full tuition for 10 consecutive full-time (up to 18 credit hours) fall and spring semesters. Scholars can also apply for up to $1,200 for an Investigative Learning Experience.
scholarships.eligibility: Awarded to exemplary student leaders. This is a competitive award, and selected students are invited to the St. Louis campus to interview and compete. ACT/SAT scores are not required.
scholarships.application_method: Separate application required. Apply for freshman admission by December 1 for priority consideration. A select group of students will be invited for interviews.

scholarships.name: Billiken, Ignatian, University, and Vice Presidents' Scholarships
scholarships.amount: $30,000 to $39,000 per year (renewable for up to 10 semesters).
scholarships.eligibility: Awarded to incoming freshmen based on previous academic performance.
scholarships.application_method: Automatic consideration when applying for freshman admission by December 1. No separate application is required.

scholarships.name: Martin Luther King Jr. Scholarship
scholarships.amount: On average, scholars receive a total of $24,000 in scholarships and aid per year from the University. This award is at least $3,000 per year and can be in addition to other SLU scholarships.
scholarships.eligibility: Recognizes students with leadership qualities and significant involvement in community service. ACT/SAT scores are not required. Transfer students are also eligible.

scholarships.name: Jesuit High School Award
scholarships.amount: $5,000 per year (renewable for up to 10 semesters).
scholarships.eligibility: Automatically awarded to applicants who graduate from a Jesuit high school.
scholarships.application_method: Automatic consideration when applying for admission. No separate application is required, but applying by December 1 is recommended for priority consideration.

ap_policy.general_rule: Qualifying scores on AP exams, subject to departmental approval and specific minimum scores for each exam, grant credit. Official score reports are required.
exceptions: No AP credit for biology, chemistry, and physics science course requirements for Pre-Professional Health Studies.
Some AP mathematics course credit might be accepted for Pre-Professional Health Studies, but it is recommended to take math courses at SLU.
ap_policy.usage: AP credits can be posted to the transcript and may satisfy some specific course requirements, major prerequisites, and general education requirements, subject to departmental evaluation.

ib_policy.general_rule: HL exams with a score of 5+ grant credit

transfer_articulation.restrictions: Maximum 64 community college credit hours (60 for School of Social Work) toward a bachelor's degree; minimum grade of 'C' or above for transfer courses; coursework must be from regionally accredited institutions. After initial enrollment at SLU (starting Fall 2025), students are limited to 9 transfer credits. Graduate students are limited to 20% of total credits (33% for School of Law). Business courses for Chaifetz School of Business must be within 5 years of review, and other courses generally within 10 years. School for Professional Studies has a 30-credit limit for business-related courses.

what_it_takes: Strong academic record with challenging coursework
Demonstrated passion and involvement in extracurricular activities and community service
Alignment with St. Louis University's Jesuit mission and values, including a commitment to service and personal growth
Motivation and dedication to a rigorous academic environment
essay_tips: Be specific about why this school  reference unique programs, courses, or aspects of SLU's mission (like academic excellence and service to others) that genuinely resonate with your goals and interests.
Show, don't tell  use concrete examples and personal anecdotes to illustrate your qualities, experiences, and how they align with SLU's values, rather than just stating them.
Avoid clichs  craft an authentic and personal narrative, steering clear of overused phrases or generic statements that won't make your essay stand out.

Connect your interests to specific resources at the school  demonstrate thorough research by mentioning how particular departments, faculty, clubs, or opportunities at SLU will help you achieve your academic and personal aspirations.
Be honest and sincere  the admissions committee is looking to learn about you as a person, so let your genuine self and enthusiasm for SLU shine through your writing.

insights.insight: Saint Louis University has a moderately selective admissions process with an acceptance rate around 75%. Admitted students typically have a GPA of 3.6-4.0 and strong standardized test scores (average SAT 1130-1340, ACT 23-31), though test scores are optional. The university employs a holistic review process, considering factors beyond academic metrics.

SLU offers a rigorous Jesuit education emphasizing critical thinking, ethics, spirituality, and compassion, with many programs ranked nationally. It is also an R1 research university, offering numerous opportunities for students to engage in groundbreaking research and apply knowledge in practical, real-world scenarios through community engagement integrated into over 150 courses.

Saint Louis University is known for its strong sense of community, supportive environment among students and faculty, and emphasis on Jesuit values such as service, social justice, and community engagement. Students frequently praise the accessibility of professors and the variety of academic resources.

outcomes.notes: Median earnings 10 years after enrollment is from the U.S. Department of Education College Scorecard. The employment rate of 92.0% represents alumni who were employed, enrolled in graduate or professional school, participating in a year of service, serving in the military, or not seeking employment within six months of their graduation. The median earnings 6 years after enrollment is an average earnings figure six years after enrolling, not specifically after graduation, and is an approximation [cite: 2 from previous search].
